primary: FAA High Altitude Airport operations guides

operational_hours.notes: Limited operational window (16 hours/day). Control tower operates same hours. No night operations permitted.
operational_hours.seasonal_notes: Temporary closure May 5-June 1 for runway maintenance (seasonal variation)

slot_requirements.notes: No slot requirement. However, landing permits may be required for specific flight types.

weather_vulnerability.weather_patterns: High-altitude mountain climate. Winter: frequent snow, ice, wind. Spring: variable. Summer: afternoon thunderstorms, wind. Fall: rapidly changing conditions.
weather_vulnerability.wind_risk: Significant - mountain valley winds can restrict operations
weather_vulnerability.mountain_turbulence: Common due to surrounding terrain and high elevation

runway_specifications.slope: Runway slopes uphill (Runway 15 preferred for landings)
runway_specifications.density_altitude_summer: Up to 11,000 feet in summer (critical performance factor)
runway_specifications.notes: Single runway with significant elevation. Runway extended from 7,006 to 8,006 feet in 2011. Sloped runway affects landing/takeoff calculations significantly. High density altitude in summer requires performance planning.
runway_specifications.performance_consideration: Density altitude can reach 11,000 feet in July-August, significantly affecting aircraft performance

crew_requirements.minimum_pilot_hours: No specific minimum, but mountain experience essential
special_training: Density altitude calculations and aircraft performance planning
Terrain awareness and obstacle clearance procedures
Single-runway operations with limited diversion options
crew_requirements.notes: FAA recommends mountain airport rating. Pilots unfamiliar with area encouraged to contact Aspen Approach (123.80) for assistance. Local knowledge highly valuable.

handling_options: De-ice pad available (east of taxiway Alpha)
handling_complexity.notes: Ground handling services available during operational hours. De-ice pad specifically for winter operations. Limited handlers; advance arrangement recommended.

congestion_metrics.airspace_complexity: Moderate - Class D airspace, mountainous terrain
congestion_metrics.notes: Single runway creates bottleneck during ski season. Peak congestion Dec-March and summer leisure periods. Mountain weather can restrict operations completely.

permits_and_clearances.notes: No formal PPR system. However, pilots should contact Aspen Approach for assistance, especially if unfamiliar with high-altitude mountain operations.

noise_restrictions.preferred_departure_routes: Standard SID procedures; Runway 33 mandatory for IFR departures with specific climb gradients
noise_restrictions.noise_complaints_risk: Low - airport in mountain area with limited residential proximity
noise_restrictions.notes: IFR departures must use Runway 33 with specific obstacle departure procedures (ODPs). VFR departures may use other runways with procedural guidance.

infrastructure_reliability.runway_maintenance: Approximately $10 million runway repair project in progress (subsurface moisture)
infrastructure_reliability.winter_maintenance: Active snow removal operations; de-ice pad maintained

security_requirements.notes: General aviation facility with minimal security requirements.

seasonal_factors.ski_season_congestion: Very High - Dec-March peak with significant delays
seasonal_factors.notes: Ski season (Dec-March) drives primary congestion. Summer (July-August) secondary peak. Winter weather frequently restricts operations. Spring (May-June) can have rapid weather changes.

backup_alternates.name: Denver International Airport
backup_alternates.notes: Major hub, better weather, but distant

alternate_airport_proximity.notes: Limited alternate options due to mountain terrain. Eagle County (67 miles) primary alternate. Denver (199 miles) distant but reliable. Weather challenges mean alternates themselves may be affected.

payment_and_fees.parking_fees: Yes - based on duration (parking often full during peak season)
payment_and_fees.notes: Landing fees decreased 2025 (from $7.75 to $6.98 for signatory airlines). General aviation fee $8.41 per 1,000 lbs. Fees billed at departure through Vector Airport Systems.

primary_challenges: Extreme high altitude (7,838 feet) requiring density altitude calculations
Winter weather severity (10-15 snow closure events annually)
Single runway operation (critical during peak seasons)
Mountain terrain with surrounding peaks to 14,000+ feet
High winds and turbulence from valley location
Ski season congestion (Dec-March) with 2x normal traffic
Weather changes can restrict operations completely
operational_advantages: Direct access to major ski resorts
summary.crew_considerations: Mountain flying experience essential. Must be proficient in high-altitude operations and density altitude calculations. Winter operations require specific training. Single runway limits flexibility. Local knowledge highly valuable - recommended to contact Aspen Approach (123.80) if unfamiliar. Understanding of mountain weather patterns critical. Aircraft performance planning essential (summer density altitude reaches 11,000 feet).
summary.planning_recommendation: Ski season (Dec-March) extremely congested with 2x normal delays - avoid if possible or plan for significant waiting time. Summer (July-August) secondary peak with thunderstorm risk. Spring/Fall (April-May, Sept-Oct) best conditions but weather changeable. Always plan for significant alternate distances (67+ miles to Eagle). Verify aircraft performance for high density altitude summer conditions. Winter operations require de-icing procedures. Weather can restrict operations completely - maintain flexibility. Single runway means any emergency or weather event can cause closure. Contact tower before entering Roaring Fork Valley for mountain flying guidance.
